case_vignette: A 60-year-old female presents with a non-healing painful ulcer on her right leg for 4 months. She says she first noticed it after she accidentally bumped into a chair. She is known for rheumatoid arthritis and hypertension, and has taken methotrexate and bisoprolol for years. According to the patient, oral antibiotics and wound debridement have only increase the size of the ulcer. Physical exam reveals a 5x5 cm fibrinous ulcer with violaceous undermined borders on her right shin.
question: What is the final diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have a non-healing painful sore on my right leg that I've had for 4 months.
Have you had any other skin issues in the past?
No, I just noticed this one after I accidentally hit my leg on a chair.
Have you noticed any changes in your skin color or texture around the sore?
Yes, the edges of the sore are kind of purple and the skin doesn't look normal; it kind of dips under.
Have you noticed any discharge or pus coming out of the sore?
Not exactly, but it does have this kind of yellowish layer on top of it.
Have you noticed any redness or swelling around the sore?
Yes, the skin around the sore is red and it's swollen.
Have you noticed any fever or chills?
No, I haven't had a fever or chills.
Have you noticed any changes in your appetite or weight?
No, my appetite and weight have stayed the same.
Have you noticed any changes in your energy levels or sleep patterns?
No, my energy levels and sleep patterns haven't changed.
Have you noticed any changes in your mood or behavior?
No, my mood and behavior have been normal.
Have you noticed any changes in your skin on other parts of your body?
No, it's just my right leg that has the problem.
Have you noticed any changes in your medical history or medications?
I've had rheumatoid arthritis and high blood pressure, and I've been taking methotrexate and bisoprolol for years.
Have you noticed any changes in your family history of skin conditions?
No, there have been no changes in my family history regarding skin conditions.
Final Diagnosis: Squamous Cell Carcinoma.

trial_0.summarized_conversation: The patient reports a non-healing painful sore on their right leg that has been present for 4 months. The patient noticed this sore after accidentally hitting their leg on a chair. The edges of the sore are purple and the skin appears abnormal, with a dip underneath. There is also a yellowish layer on top of the sore, and the skin around it is red and swollen. The patient denies experiencing fever or chills, and states that their appetite, weight, energy levels, sleep patterns, mood, and behavior have all remained normal. The issue is localized to the right leg. The patient has a history of rheumatoid arthritis and high blood pressure, and has been taking methotrexate and bisoprolol for years. There have been no reported changes in the family history of skin conditions.
trial_0.vignette_frq: The final diagnosis is likely to be a chronic venous ulcer due to underlying rheumatoid arthritis and hypertension.
trial_0.summarized_frq: The final diagnosis is likely a chronic ulcerative lesion, possibly due to a combination of rheumatoid arthritis and high blood pressure.
